Award.AbstractNarration:
The Materials Research Science and Engineering Center (MRSEC) at the University of Southern Mississippi supports an interdisciplinary research program in the area of polymer coatings and films. The Center also supports a wide range of educational activities, including the establishment of advanced degrees in polymer education and a new course leading to an advanced degree in Distance Leaming. The Center is entitled the Response-Driven Polymeric Films Center. The Center supports well maintained and accessible shared experimental facilities and interacts with industry and other sectors at local, regional, national and international levels.

The Center's research is organized into two interdisciplinary research groups (IRGS).
IRG 1, Design and Synthesis ofresponse -Driven Poymers, focuses on the the design and synthesis of molecular processes in biomaterials, liquid crystals, and environmentally fismart" molecules. IRG 2, Response-Driven Film Formation, conducts molecular level investigations of films and coatings that exhibit response-driven properties. Potential application of the Center's research are in diveres areas such as water treatment, controlled drug release, and formulation of water-based coatings.. In addition, seed support is provided for emerging research opportunities which are within the general scope of the Center.

Participants in the Center currently include 19 senior investigators, 2 postdoctoral associates, 30 graduate students, 12 undergraduates, and 6 technicians and other support personnel. Professor Marek W. Urban directs the MRSEC.

Project Outcome Report; PI – Marek W. Urban, Center Director

Center for Stimuli-Responsive Polymeric Films and Coatings (DMR 0213883)

 

Intellectual Merit

In 2002, the researchers at the University of Southern Mississippi led by Prof. Marek W. Urban, Center Director, established the Center for Stimuli-Responsive Polymeric Films and Coatings funded by the National Science Foundation Materials Research Science and Engineering Center program (DMR 0213883). The Center developed and significantly contributed to understanding of fundamental principles governing stimuli-responsive behaviors in materials, development of scientific principles governing stimuli-response behaviors of macromolecules in complex environments, understanding of response-driven film formation and response polymeric films, time-property relationships, and Integration of research and education programs. The Center developed a new generation of stimuli-responsive polymeric materials that mimic Mother Nature. The discoveries ranging from controllable polymer synthesis under environmentally compliant conditions to self-healing polymers and antimicrobial surfaces are examples of the intellectual merits that stimulated other researchers worldwide. The achievements are documented in over two hundred twenty peer-reviewed research publications published in Science, Nature, and other materials and polymer sciences journals.  

 

Broader Impact

This Center had a variety of impacts not only on those directly involved in research, but on the entire community, the state, and the nation. There are four areas of broader impact, which include educational, social, economical, and national impacts. These efforts implemented by MRSEC have left permanent marks on the culture and the infrastructure of research and education. Notable examples are Shared Facilities consisting of the following Clusters: Synthesis, Scale-up, and Film Preparation, Spectroscopic Instrumentation with NMR Facility, Vibrational Spectroscopy Cluster, UV and Fluorescence Spectroscopy, Chromatographic Cluster, Morphological and Surface Science, Thermo-Mechanical and Rheological.

Several patents have resulted from MRSEC discoveries that have led to the formation of startup companies on in the region. The major impact of MRSEC funding was on the education and training of the future cadre of scientists. This Center graduated over 30 PhD students and supported highly successful postdoctoral students who had no difficulty competing for employment in top chemical and polymer companies worldwide. These achievements could no be possible without outstanding research and education offered by the Center faculty who impacted over 2,500 high school students and teachers. 

The Center facilitated startup funds for hiring new junior faculty, resulted in the development of shared facilities network, instrumentation purchases for all MRSEC participating units, development of remote access to instrumentation, establishment of international collaborations, numerous outreach activities for our students including under-represented minorities, summer Research Experience for Undergraduates programs.
